summary: This paper presents two novel peptide encoding methods based on physicochemical properties of amino acids, aiming to improve classification accuracy in peptide-related machine learning tasks. The effectiveness of these methods is demonstrated through extensive comparisons with existing encoding techniques across different classification problems, including HIV-protease, T-cell epitopes, and human leukocyte antigens binding peptides.
formulas: Pp_20+k = 1 / (M - k) * sum(a=1 to M-k) [val(p, Aa) - val(p, Aa+k)]
relationships: The physicochemical properties of amino acids influence the effectiveness of peptide encodings in classification tasks.
The performance of peptide classification systems can be enhanced by using ensemble methods that combine different classifiers or feature sets.

The introduction of novel encoding methods based on physicochemical properties and supervised feature transformation (like PCA and NLF) improves the classification accuracy compared to traditional methods.
variables: Pp_20+k: The k-th physicochemical property in the pseudo amino acid composition encoding
M: Length of the peptide sequence
Aa: Amino acid at position a in the peptide sequence
val(p, Aa): Normalized value of the physicochemical property p for the amino acid at position a
EUC: Error under the ROC curve
AUC: Area under the ROC curve
key_ideas: Introduction of two novel encoding methods for peptides based on physicochemical properties, which show superior performance in classification tasks.
Extensive comparison of new and existing encoding methods across multiple datasets and classification problems demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed methods.
Use of ensemble classifiers and feature perturbation techniques to enhance the performance of peptide classification systems.
Application of supervised feature transformation techniques, such as PCA and NLF, to derive effective encoding schemes for peptides.
